plan.title: Part 1: Land Preparation & Sowing
plan.description: Plough the field 2-3 times to obtain fine tilth. Mix 8-10 tons of well-decomposed FYM per acre. Level the field for uniform moisture. Sow seeds at 30-45 cm row spacing and 10-15 cm plant spacing. Seed rate: 4-5 kg per acre. Treat seeds with Thiram or Carbendazim @3 g/kg to prevent fungal attack.
plan.completion_check: Are the seeds sown evenly at recommended spacing and depth?
highlights: Optimum sowing depth: 2-3 cm for uniform germination.
Early land preparation helps control initial weeds.
Ensure good soil moisture at sowing.

plan.title: Part 2: Week 1-2 – Germination & Seedling Establishment
plan.description: Seeds germinate in 5-7 days. Maintain light irrigation if required. Avoid waterlogging. Monitor for uniform stand and thin weak seedlings.
plan.completion_check: Have seedlings emerged evenly and are 3-4 inches tall?
highlights: Thin plants to maintain single healthy plant per stand.
Watch for cutworms and early pests.
Apply neem-based pesticide if shoot damage is visible.

plan.title: Part 3: Week 3-5 – Early Growth & First Weeding
plan.description: Perform the first intercultural weeding to remove competing weeds. Apply first dose of nitrogen fertilizer (25 kg N per acre) as side-dressing. Maintain soil moisture to support vegetative growth.
plan.completion_check: Has first weeding and fertilizer been applied correctly?
highlights: Use hand hoe or wheel hoe for effective weed control.
Do not disturb roots while hoeing.
Monitor for early shoot fly attack.

plan.title: Part 4: Week 6-8 – Tillering & Vegetative Stage
plan.description: Plants actively tiller. Apply second dose of nitrogen (20 kg N per acre) and 10 kg K₂O per acre. Maintain clean fields and monitor for pests like stem borer.
plan.completion_check: Are plants tall with multiple healthy tillers?
highlights: Apply fertilizer near the base and irrigate lightly.
Check for aphids and midge damage.
Maintain 5-7 cm soil moisture in rainfed fields.

plan.title: Part 5: Week 9-11 – Booting & Panicle Initiation
plan.description: Panicle initiation begins. Maintain soil moisture and nutrient supply. Avoid drought stress at this stage to ensure proper grain set.
plan.completion_check: Are panicles emerging uniformly and plants deep green?
highlights: Apply 10-15 kg N as top dressing if plants appear pale.
Protect from stem borer and midge with recommended insecticides.
Keep field weed-free to prevent competition for nutrients.

plan.title: Part 6: Week 12-14 – Flowering Stage
plan.description: Ensure optimal moisture during flowering. Avoid fertilizer sprays during anthesis. Monitor pollination for uniform grain formation.
plan.completion_check: Are flowering panicles fully open and pollinating?
highlights: Avoid nitrogen application — prevents lodging.
Inspect for midge and aphid attacks and treat promptly.
Maintain shallow water layer if irrigated.

plan.title: Part 7: Week 15-17 – Grain Filling & Maturity
plan.description: Panicles begin grain filling. Reduce irrigation gradually. Ensure balanced nutrients for proper grain development. Avoid pest infestation during this stage.
plan.completion_check: Are grains firm, filling, and turning golden?
highlights: Stop irrigation 10-12 days before harvest to allow grain hardening.
Protect from earhead midge and grain mold under humid conditions.
Bird control may be needed in open fields.

plan.title: Part 8: Week 18-20 – Harvesting
plan.description: Harvest when grains are hard and moisture content is ~20%. Cut earheads or whole plant depending on use (grain/fodder).
plan.completion_check: Are grains hardened and ready for threshing?
highlights: Harvest in clear weather to prevent fungal attack.
Thresh soon after harvesting.
Avoid over-drying to prevent grain breakage.

plan.title: Part 9: Post-Harvest Drying & Storage
plan.description: Clean, sun-dry, and store grains at 12-14% moisture in aerated conditions to prevent pests and molds.
plan.completion_check: Are grains properly dried and safely stored?
highlights: Store in gunny or HDPE bags on raised platforms.
Use neem leaves or natural repellents if storing long-term.
Avoid damp and dark storage spaces.

plan.title: Part 10: Pest & Disease Management (Ongoing)
plan.description: Monitor for major pests like shoot fly, stem borer, midge, and aphids. Diseases include downy mildew, smut, and ergot. Apply integrated pest management (IPM) practices as needed.
plan.completion_check: Is the field free from major pest and disease outbreaks?
highlights: Shoot Fly: Deadheart in seedlings — use seed treatment with Imidacloprid.
Stem Borer: Leaf whorl damage — remove infested shoots.
Downy Mildew: Apply fungicide seed treatment if prevalent.
Rotate Bajra with legumes to reduce soil-borne pests.

plan.title: Part 1: Land Preparation & Sucker Selection
plan.description: Plough the field 2–3 times to get fine tilth. Incorporate 10–12 tons of well-decomposed FYM per acre. Select healthy, disease-free suckers for planting, preferably 10–12 months old with 2–3 functional leaves.
plan.completion_check: Is the land prepared and suckers selected properly?
highlights: Well-drained loamy soil with pH 5.5–6.5 is ideal.
Healthy suckers ensure faster establishment and higher yield.
Organic matter improves soil structure and fertility.

plan.title: Part 2: Planting
plan.description: Plant suckers in pits of 60×60×60 cm or trenches filled with topsoil and compost. Maintain spacing of 2.5–3 m between rows and 2–2.5 m between plants. Ensure proper alignment of the corm.
plan.completion_check: Are suckers planted at proper spacing and depth?
highlights: Plant at the beginning of rainy season or with adequate irrigation.
Correct planting depth prevents root suffocation and promotes establishment.
Proper spacing ensures air circulation and light penetration.

plan.title: Part 3: Week 1–8 – Establishment & Initial Care
plan.description: Maintain uniform soil moisture with frequent light irrigation. Apply starter NPK fertilizer (20–25 kg N, 10 kg P₂O₅, 10 kg K₂O per acre) lightly around plants. Remove weeds manually.
plan.completion_check: Are suckers established and free from weeds?
highlights: Avoid waterlogging to prevent root rot.
Mulching conserves moisture and suppresses weeds.
Early nutrient supply promotes strong vegetative growth.

plan.title: Part 4: Week 9–16 – Vegetative Growth & Fertilization
plan.description: Apply NPK fertilizer (40–50 kg N, 20 kg P₂O₅, 40–50 kg K₂O per acre) in split doses. Remove excess suckers to maintain one main plant per pit. Support tall plants with props to prevent lodging.
plan.completion_check: Has fertilizer application and sucker management been done?
highlights: Nitrogen supports leaf growth, potassium enhances fruit quality.
Removing extra suckers reduces competition for nutrients.
Props prevent wind or rain damage to tall plants.

plan.title: Part 5: Week 17–24 – Flower Initiation & Bunch Development
plan.description: Banana plants start producing the inflorescence. Maintain adequate moisture. Apply potassium-rich fertilizer to support bunch development. Protect flower buds from insects and birds using nets or covers.
plan.completion_check: Are flower buds emerging and bunches developing properly?
highlights: Potassium enhances fruit size, weight, and shelf life.
Regular irrigation prevents moisture stress during flowering.
Flower protection reduces physical damage and pest attacks.

plan.title: Part 6: Week 25–40 – Fruit Filling & Maturation
plan.description: Fruits fill and mature. Maintain regular irrigation, mulching, and nutrient supply. Apply foliar sprays of micronutrients like boron and zinc if deficient. Monitor for pests such as banana weevil, aphids, and nematodes, and diseases like Panama wilt and Sigatoka.
plan.completion_check: Are fruits filling properly and plants healthy?
highlights: Potassium-rich nutrition enhances bunch weight and fruit quality.
Regular monitoring prevents yield loss from pests and diseases.
Mulching conserves moisture and moderates soil temperature.

plan.title: Part 7: Pre-Harvest & Harvesting
plan.description: Stop heavy fertilization 2–3 weeks before harvest. Harvest fruits when they reach appropriate size, fullness, and color. Use poles or knives to cut bunches carefully. Handle fruits gently to avoid bruising.
plan.completion_check: Are bananas harvested at optimal maturity and handled properly?
highlights: Harvest at correct maturity to ensure optimal taste and shelf life.
Avoid mechanical damage to maintain fruit quality.
Timely harvest reduces pest attacks and fruit drop.

plan.title: Part 8: Post-Harvest Handling & Storage
plan.description: Transport harvested bunches to shaded, ventilated areas. For longer storage or ripening, maintain temperature 14–18°C. Inspect for pests, bruises, or fungal infections.
plan.completion_check: Are harvested bananas stored or transported correctly?
highlights: Shaded and ventilated storage reduces spoilage.
Temperature control extends shelf life for market or ripening.
Regular inspection prevents post-harvest losses.

plan.title: Part 9: Pest & Disease Management (Ongoing)
plan.description: Monitor for banana weevil, aphids, nematodes; and diseases like Panama wilt, Sigatoka, and bunch rot. Apply integrated pest management (IPM) practices and fungicides as necessary.
plan.completion_check: Is the banana crop free from major pest and disease outbreaks?
highlights: Regular scouting prevents severe infestations.
Sanitation and removing infected plants reduce disease spread.
Use resistant varieties and biological control whenever possible.

Seed treatment improves early growth and nitrogen fixation.

highlights: Uniform sowing reduces competition and ensures better yield.
Avoid waterlogged soils; black gram is sensitive to excess moisture.
Early sowing ensures full flowering and pod formation.

highlights: Avoid waterlogging; seedlings are sensitive to excess moisture.
Thin weak seedlings to maintain optimal plant population.
Monitor for damping-off disease and treat if necessary.

plan.title: Part 4: Week 3-5 – Vegetative Growth & Fertilizer Application
plan.description: Apply phosphorus (20 kg P₂O₅/acre) and potassium (10 kg K₂O/acre) if soil is deficient. Maintain weed-free field and proper soil moisture for vigorous growth.
plan.completion_check: Has fertilizer application and weeding been done?
highlights: Phosphorus promotes root growth and nodulation.
Weeding prevents competition and improves nutrient availability.
Scout for early pests like aphids or leaf miner.

plan.title: Part 5: Week 6-7 – Flowering Initiation
plan.description: Flowering begins. Maintain adequate soil moisture. Monitor for pests such as pod borer and aphids. Avoid water stress during flowering for proper pod set.
plan.completion_check: Are flowers emerging uniformly and plants healthy?
highlights: Critical stage for pod formation and yield.
Use neem-based sprays or bio-pesticides for pest control.
Keep fields weed-free to reduce nutrient competition.

plan.title: Part 6: Week 8-10 – Pod Formation & Grain Filling
plan.description: Pods develop and grains start filling. Apply additional potassium (10–15 kg K₂O/acre) if deficient. Maintain adequate moisture for proper grain filling.
plan.completion_check: Are pods forming and grains filling properly?
highlights: Protect crop from pod borer, aphids, and leaf miner.
Avoid waterlogging; intermittent moisture is preferred.
Ensure nutrient supply for optimal grain filling.

plan.title: Part 7: Week 11-12 – Maturity
plan.description: Stop irrigation 10–12 days before harvest. Allow pods to mature and grains to harden. Monitor for late-stage pests or fungal infections.
plan.completion_check: Are pods turning yellow and grains hardened?
highlights: Harvest when 90% of pods are yellow-brown and dry.
Avoid premature harvesting; reduces seed weight.
Field sanitation reduces post-harvest pest problems.

plan.title: Part 8: Week 13 – Harvesting

plan.completion_check: Has the crop been harvested and grains dried?

Avoid harvesting during rain to prevent mold growth.
Handle pods gently to avoid shattering.

plan.title: Part 9: Post-Harvest Handling & Storage

plan.completion_check: Are grains properly dried and safely stored?
highlights: Avoid damp storage to prevent mold or insect infestation.
Apply neem leaves or natural repellents for long-term storage.
Label bags with variety and harvest date.

plan.completion_check: Is the field free from major pest and disease outbreaks?
